ld.headline: Tweezers Trading Strategy – Tweezer Top & Bottom Reversal Patterns

hero.title: Tweezers Strategy
hero.subtitle: The Tweezers strategy identifies potential tops and bottoms in the market using a simple two-candle reversal pattern. It provides early visual clues of a trend reversal when prices reject the same level twice — once on each candle.

video.aria: The Tweezers strategy is a candlestick reversal pattern used to signal potential tops and bottoms in the market.

items.1: The Tweezers strategy is a candlestick reversal pattern that highlights potential tops and bottoms in price action.
items.2: It forms when two consecutive candles have nearly identical highs or lows, suggesting strong rejection at a key level.
items.3: There are two types of tweezers: the Tweezer Top (bearish reversal) and the Tweezer Bottom (bullish reversal).

1.label: Formation
1.text: Occurs at the end of an uptrend with two consecutive candles having almost identical highs.

2.label: First Candlestick
2.text: Typically a bullish candle showing strong upward momentum before rejection.

3.label: Second Candlestick
3.text: A bearish candle with a similar high, showing resistance at the same price level.

4.label: Confirmation
4.text: The reversal is confirmed when the next candle closes below the Tweezer pattern’s low.

1.label: Formation
1.text: Appears at the end of a downtrend when two candles have nearly identical lows.

2.label: First Candlestick
2.text: Usually a bearish candle continuing the trend before buyers step in.

3.label: Second Candlestick
3.text: A bullish candle with the same low, signaling support and buying strength.

4.label: Confirmation
4.text: Confirmed when the next candle closes above the Tweezer pattern’s high.

items.1: Look for Tweezer Tops or Bottoms near key support or resistance levels for higher accuracy.
items.2: Combine with indicators like RSI to confirm overbought or oversold conditions.
items.3: Set stop-losses just above the Tweezer Top or below the Tweezer Bottom to manage risk effectively.

items.1: Simple pattern – easy to identify using only two consecutive candles.
items.2: Reliable reversal signal near major support/resistance zones.
items.3: Works well with confirmation tools like RSI, MACD, or trendlines.

items.1: Requires confirmation to avoid false reversal signals.
items.2: Less reliable in ranging or low-volume markets.
items.3: Can be misleading if used alone without other analysis tools.
